qas.question: What kind of motor can employ both AC and DC?
What component of a universal motor is most likely to fail?
When is torque most important in universal motor applications?
Switching the field winding in washing machines causes the drum to agitate how?
How is stepped speed control achieved?

answers.text: Multiple taps on the field coil provide

qas.question: What kind of motor can employ both DC and DC?
What component of a universal motor is most likely to not fail?
When is torque least important in universal motor applications?
Switching the field winding out of washing machines causes the drum to agitate how?

context: An advantage of the <a0_0><b5_0>universal<b5_0/><a0_0/> motor is that AC supplies may be used on motors which have some characteristics more common in DC motors, specifically high starting torque and very compact design if high running speeds are used. The negative aspect is the maintenance and short life problems caused by the <a1_0><b6_0>commutator<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Such motors are used in devices such as food mixers and power tools which are used only intermittently, and often have high <a2_0><b7_0>starting<b7_0/><a2_0/>-torque demands. <a4_0>Multiple taps on the field coil provide<a4_0/> (imprecise) stepped speed control. Household blenders that advertise many speeds frequently combine a field coil with several taps and a diode that can be inserted in series with the motor (causing the motor to run on half-wave rectified AC). Universal motors also lend themselves to electronic speed control and, as such, are an ideal choice for devices like domestic washing machines. The motor can be used to agitate the drum (both <a3_0><b8_0>forwards and in reverse<b8_0/><a3_0/>) by switching the field winding with respect to the armature.
